the problem is sadly not Minecraft, I hate to break it to you put the problem is that the switch was severely underpowered when it released 8 years ago, its incredibly slow now.

Please Mojang.

I have an RTX PC but I honestly don't like RTX that much, it uses 100% of my GPU at all time, it limits my render distance, and it is not very visually appealing.

Please somehow bring back shaders. Many people love shaders and many people that cannot/don't want to use RTX.

I understand Nvidia probably wants everyone to get an RTX machine but not everyone can afford it. Where did the goal to make Minecraft accessible and fair to everyone go?

Dear Minecraft Team,

I hope this message finds you well. First and foremost, I would like to express my appreciation for the incredible work you've done in creating and maintaining Minecraft Pocket Edition. It has provided countless hours of entertainment and creativity for players all around the world, myself included.

I am writing to offer a suggestion that I believe would enhance the communication experience within Minecraft Pocket Edition. As emojis have become an integral part of modern communication, I would like to request the addition of emoji support to the in-game chat feature. Incorporating emojis would not only allow players to express themselves more effectively but also make the chat system more engaging and enjoyable.
Minecraft username :- ReverseKrishYT
Discord ID :- Its_krish#7975

(Bedrock Edition)
Absolutely needs to be an option to increase entity render distance.

Having 2 new sliders would be great

I really hate playing the game with 30 chunk render distance and just seeing things disappear so close to me, especially players.
It just seems dumb to restrict other platforms just because some play on mobile and they can only handle 4 chunks entity distance.
I'd argue that on average those on pc's and consoles play this game longer on average instead of short bursts which is likely how most play on mobile.

Just give us the OPTION to change some of these things for our own use cases and systems.
But seeing as how it took a while to get higher render distances, it may be an engine issue more than just the hardware not being capable.

The player death animation should depend on the death scene/the way they died

(excess formatting removed by admin)

Expanding on this idea: there should be an option in the world menu to toggle "Death Animations" if people prefer the original, simple way. That way people won't hate Mojang for adding something they don't like.

Currently axolotls fall over and lay still whenever they "play dead." While the feature may just be so players can still find them and no monsters notice them, I think it would be cool if axolotls matched other mobs deaths. For example, they could fall over and then simply turn invisible or teleport away, making it appear like they died until they reappear. You would know that they didn't die as they wouldn't turn red when they disappear.

Alternatively, mob deaths could be similar to how axolotls die, where they fall over but stay on the ground a bit until they fade away. That way, players could expect the same thing for axolotls, except they wouldn't fade away

I do agree that the rendering engine on java edition could use some changes, but I believe that the opposite of what you said is true - that Minecraft doesn't use enough GPU power.

The reason that the bedrock edition of the game runs so smoothly is that it offloads a lot of rendering tasks to the GPU, so it's less taxing on the CPU. The java edition makes the CPU do a lot of the work that the GPU does on the bedrock edition, which likely why you can run more graphically detailed games but struggle to run Minecraft in some cases. As a result, it works great on powerful CPUs and integrated graphics, but in more complex scenes, systems with weaker CPUs will struggle regardless of what graphics card is being used. If Minecraft were able to offload more of the rendering to the GPU, it would probably improve performance.

The other issue with just using render dragon for java edition is that it would probably break a lot of resource packs, since it handles UV and texture mapping differently.

I think they should update to vulkan rather than Direct3D. Since Vulkan is an advanced version of OpenGL.
This could lead to some cool stuff like having Vulkan Ray tracing on java.

Right now the full cube blocks have slightly shaded sides, the top side being the brightest, north and south being slightly darker, and east west being slightly darker still. All blocks have the same shading, so, what if instead of having one fixed shading, there is a pre rendered shading directly connected to the day-night cycle, that shifts brightness on each side according to the sun and moons movement, that all the blocks can use in the same way as before, just sort of animated?
[edit part: it would need to be connected to what block was lit by daylight for it to make sense? and have the old shading for all other blocks as a default]

That would probably be relatively cheap compared to how much more alive minecraft would feel?
